entry.title: Re: Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters – A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration
entry.content:
1. Implementation and Real-Life Use

ISA-M > Integration Suite , Integration Assessment is one capability Integration Suite. It will not "really" help you to “prioritize interfaces for modernization” but rather helps with the technology decision itself ( what to use).

Most efficient way to categorize existing interface depends a bit on your landscape, but I would define my (1) Transformation Strategy in LeanIX, (2) maintain my Integration Technologies in LeanIX + replicate the same to INTAS, (3) check INTAS Master Data und your Integration policies (4) Replicate interfaces from e.g. SAP PO (content below) to LeanIX > build up Interface Repo, replicate the same to INTAS ( for technology decision) and CALM ( project Management).

If you use e.g. ServiceNow or Confluent the setup could be a bit different for sure.

 

2. Integration Strategy and Governance

ISA-M itself is a framework which moved to Integration Suite, Integration Assessment: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/what-is-integration-assessment

See some of the features to enforce the usage.

  • Capture ISA-M technology mapping and policies.

Use ISA-M master data that is available with the framework and enrich this data with more context information.

  • Perform a guided interface request process.

Apply ISA-M policies and guidelines during the interface request process.

The interface request process helps you to decide on the integration technology that best suits your organization's integration strategy. It provides guidance during the technology selection phase.

  • Use questionnaires.

Questionnaires help you to make the right technology decisions. You can also create custom questions to determine the right integration technology.

But it I would see exception management / Integration Control Board (ICB) not in INTAS; but either in other tools ( mix of CALM and/or LeanIX or event 3rd party)

3. Tooling and Automation

You could make usage of the given APIs and connect some of the dots (not all yet). I currently focus on LeanIX as central EAM Tool, INTAS as Integration Governance Tool and CALM for Project Management

Some accelerators:

Integration Assessment: https://api.sap.com/package/SAPIntegrationAssessment/odata

SAP LeanIX Integration with SAP Integration Suite

https://api.sap.com/package/SAPLeanIXIntegrationwithSAPIntegrationSuite/integrationflow

SAP LeanIX Integration with SAP Cloud Integration

https://api.sap.com/package/SAPLeanIXIntegrationwithSAPCloudIntegration/integrationflow   

SAP LeanIX Integration with SAP Process Orchestration

https://api.sap.com/package/SAPLeanIXIntegrationwithSAPProcessOrchestration/integrationflow

LeanIX: https://help.sap.com/docs/leanix/ea/sap-leanix-apis


CALM: https://api.sap.com/package/SAPCloudALM/odatav4

For the overall story/flow I plan to release another blog, SAP Integrated Toolchain, Interface Management( based on ISA-M) this year.

In my current vision I only see the project management of Interface Development in CALM ( e.g. https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/projektmanagement-mit-sap-cloud-alm/ba-p/13553129) and less ISA-M flavor itself.

4. Clean Core and Event-Driven Architecture

SAP is shipping info /context for SAP technologies inside INTAS as ISA-M master data sets.

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/review-integration-technology

The latest Technology Profile (provided by SAP) you could check within INTAS itself.

Here one of the latest SAP Note in regards API Technology usage in context of Clean Core: https://me.sap.com/notes/3578329

+ check the recording in my original blog

5. Community Best Practices and Change Management

The main pitfalls I see:

  • ISA-M not operationalized, only blueprints created, but not embedded in Interface Development process along the Toolchain
  • ISA-M not updated

Success Story: https://www.sap.com/documents/2023/08/802b9fcb-837e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html

entry.title: Re: Web application health check monitoring: SAP Alert Notification Service & SAP Automation Pilot r
entry.content:
Dear Biser, 

Congratulations on a great blog post, I have implemented a similar scenario combining the SAP Automation Pilot and SAP Alert Notification Service. One question came up during my work: is it also possible to get notified by email (via ANS) in case a scheduled execution runs into an error? 

I tried to set this up creating a new condition with eventType = ScheduledExecutionStatusChanged  (as described here: https://help.sap.com/docs/alert-notification/sap-alert-notification-for-sap-btp/sap-automation-pilot-scheduled-execution-status-change?locale=en-US) and a subscription that listens to the condition and combines with an e-mail action. 

I set up my scheduled execution to run into status ERROR but did not receive any notification by mail. Do you know of any setup step that I might have overlooked? 

Thanks in advance for your input, 

Kind regards, 

Lena

entry.title: CI-DS - Data visibility in IBP is not correct
entry.content:
My requirement is to load the data into the keyfigure using the master data file. so I created keyfiguredate as 20250101, 20260101 to avoid making the file too big (for example PRD1 LOC1 SourceID1 combination will have 156 lines and so on).

As my key figure disaggregation mode is 'COPY VALUE' so it should just copy across the entire horizon, which is working fine when i upload the data manually through Data integration app by selecting year in Key figure and data is disaggregated to Week level

When I use CI-DS to upload the file. in IBP, it is not showing up at technical week level. 

Is it possible somehow through CI-DS?

I am using query mapping as (to_date(to_char(FILE_EXPORT_COMP_COEFFICIENT.KEYFIGUREDATE, 'YYYYMMDD'), 'YYYYMMDD')) and transformation mapping (ifthenelse(QueryAndFilter.KEYFIGUREDATE is NULL, sysdate(), QueryAndFilter.KEYFIGUREDATE - day_in_week(QueryAndFilter.KEYFIGUREDATE) + 1), also using the global parameter in the execution properties as '$G_TIME_PROFILE_LEVEL = '2' (Time profile id - Week Technical) but can't see the data at technical week level.

entry.title: Re: Regarding SAP Signavio Certification
entry.content:
Dear Shirin, 

If you want to have more of an overview of SAP Signavio and the Transformation suite we recommend to go for option 2 "SAP Certified Associate - Process Management Consultant " which is intended for professionals who manage business processes with SAP Signavio solutions. 
It validates that the candidate possesses fundamental knowledge for managing and designing business processes with customer experience at the heart of the process design. This one is also recommended as an entry level qualification.

If you afterwards feel like you need a deep dive into mining and analytics you can proceed with "SAP Certified Associate - Process Data Analyst - SAP Signavio"  where you will understand how to use Process Intelligence and Process Insights for investigations and make recommendations for improvements.

We hope that is sufficient . 

Have a great day

entry.title: Document Compression in DMS.
entry.content:
We are currently using the Document Management Service, Integration Option in our production system on SAP BTP. We have observed that all documents being attached via our application are getting stored in their original size within the DMS.

We would like to understand why the documents are not being compressed before being stored in DMS. Additionally, we are looking for guidance on the following:

  1. Is document compression supported during upload/attachment in the DMS (Integration Option)?

  2. If yes, what configurations or custom implementations are required to enable compression of attachments before they are stored?

  3. Are there any recommended best practices or tools to handle this compression efficiently within the BTP ecosystem

entry.title: Adoption of PO price from purchase requisition for confugured material
entry.content:
Hello,

We have a configured material whose price in the purchase requisition is determined by the BOM for our intercompany process ( we developed some logic to transfer the EK02 condition from sales order to PREQ). The problem come when converting the purchase requisition to a PO. The PO overwrites the PREQ price with either PIR or last PO price, I understand this is standard SAP behaviour.

My question is is there a way to default the PREQ price automatically for configured materials when converting to PO.

Many thanks

entry.title: 2 Outbound Delivery getting Created for 2 Line item of Sub-contracting PO in ADSUBCON T.Code
entry.content:
Hi All,

Two deliveries will be created because in PO items items have different requirements data on the component level. Please Maintain the same requirement date for all components in Material tab of Iine items details

You cannot expect two items in the same delivery with different requirements date.

 

Thanks 
Sati

entry.title: Re: Update pricing in outbound delivery
entry.content:
Hi @Head_CCC ,

Thank you. this solution works for me. 

In include - MV50AFZ1 subroutine-userexit_save_document_prepare the pricing details from IDOC should be appended to this standard internal table tkomv[].

Then in outbound delivery, you can see the prices are updated in header-condition tab and values are updated in KONV table. But the issue is some values are hardcodes in this code and it needs to be fetched based on IMG configuration.

it should be optimized further with no hardcodes of values.

IF likp-lgnum = 'XXX'.
key = 'ZZ_XXX'.
IMPORT lt_exten2 TO lt_exten2 FROM DATABASE indx(zz) ID key.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
FREE MEMORY ID key.
SORT lt_exten2 BY kschl kbetr.
DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_exten2 COMPARING kschl kbetr.
ENDIF.
IF likp-knump IS INITIAL.
CALL FUNCTION 'NUMBER_GET_NEXT'
EXPORTING
nr_range_nr = '01'
object = 'KONV'
IMPORTING
number = likp-knump.
ENDIF.
SELECT zaehk FROM konv INTO TABLE lt_zaehk
WHERE KNUMV = likp-knump.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
SORT lt_zaehk BY zaehk DESCENDING.
DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM lt_zaehk COMPARING zaehk.
lv_max = lt_zaehk[ 1 ].
lv_max = lv_max + 1.
ENDIF.
IF lv_max IS INITIAL.
lv_max = 1.
ENDIF.

SELECT SINGLE * FROM T683S INTO ls_t683s where kvewe = 'A'
AND kappl = 'V'
AND kalsm = 'ZRVCPZ'
AND stunr = '860'.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
LOOP AT lt_exten2 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lf_exten2>).
MOVE-CORRESPONDING ls_t683s TO ls_komv.
ls_komv-knumv = likp-knump.
ls_komv-kposn = '000000'.
ls_komv-zaehk = lv_max.
ls_komv-krech = 'B'.
ls_komv-kawrt = '1000.00'.
ls_komv-kschl = <lf_exten2>-kschl.
ls_komv-kbetr = <lf_exten2>-kbetr.
ls_komv-waers = 'EUR'.
ls_komv-kntyp = 'F'.
ls_komv-kherk = 'C'.
ls_komv-kgrpe = 'X'.
ls_komv-kwert = ls_komv-kbetr.
ls_komv-ksteu = 'C'.
ls_komv-koaid = 'A'.
ls_komv-zaeko = ls_komv-zaehk.
ls_komv-kmprs = 'X'.
ls_komv-kmanu = 'C'.
ls_komv-knega = 'A'.
ls_komv-kaend_btr = 'X'.
ls_komv-kaend_loe = 'X'.
APPEND ls_komv to lt_komv.
CLEAR ls_komv.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING ls_t683s TO ls_komv.
ls_komv-knumv = likp-knump.
ls_komv-kposn = '000010'.
ls_komv-zaehk = lv_max.
ls_komv-krech = 'B'.
ls_komv-kawrt = '1000.00'.
ls_komv-kschl = <lf_exten2>-kschl.
ls_komv-kbetr = <lf_exten2>-kbetr.
ls_komv-waers = 'EUR'.
ls_komv-kntyp = 'F'.
ls_komv-kherk = 'D'.
ls_komv-kgrpe = 'X'.
ls_komv-kwert = ls_komv-kbetr.
ls_komv-ksteu = 'C'.
ls_komv-koaid = 'A'.
ls_komv-zaeko = ls_komv-zaehk.
ls_komv-kmprs = 'X'.
CLEAR: ls_komv-drukz,ls_komv-kzwiw,ls_komv-kofra.
APPEND ls_komv to lt_komv.
lv_max = lv_max + 1.
CLEAR: ls_komv.
ENDLOOP.
IF <lf_exten2> IS ASSIGNED.
UNASSIGN <lf_exten2>.
ENDIF.
CLEAR: ls_t683s,lv_max.
ENDIF.
SORT lt_komv BY knumv kposn stunr zaehk.
APPEND LINES OF lt_komv TO tkomv.
SORT tkomv BY knumv kposn stunr zaehk.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Ewelina Siudzińska
entry.content:
More about Ewelina Siudzińska in SAP Community


First Name, Last Name: Ewelina Siudzińska
Location (City, Country): Katowice, Poland
Occupation: SAP Consultant (BW & BI)

 

 


Ewelina, tell us about yourself.
Who are you, what do you like to do, what is important to you?

My family says I am hard-working and determined. My friends say I am well-organized and reliable. I think I am just authentic and myself. Most the time, I go against the flow! I do not listen to music that everyone else listens to, and I do not spend my holidays on a sunbed with an all-inclusive package. Instead, I choose  conscious travelling with every hour of sightseeing planned out 😉 and as much physical activity as possible. I try to keep a good work-life balance. My work and personal development are very important to me, and I spend a lot of time working towards my goals. But living my own life is also important to me. Sports such as fitness, cycling, walking, and swimming help me achieve this on an ordinary day. I enjoy reading crime novels, and when I do not have time for that, I listen to audiobooks while doing other daily activities. I love cooking and enjoy trying new flavors during my travels.


What is your area of expertise?
What does a usual day at work look like for you?

I work as SAP BI and BW consultant. I specialize in designing and implementing operational and strategic reports. These are primarily activities aimed at working closely with functional teams to understand reporting needs and deliver solutions that meet business objectives. The icing on the cake is the creation of interactive dashboards in SAC based on models I built in SAP BW. I collaborate on system upgrades, enhancements, and migrations. My tasks also entail maintaining extractors from SAP ERP, but also deploying standard and custom extractors from the S/4HANA system. This involves collaborating with teams responsible for handling subscribers’ queues.


What inspired you to become an SAP Champion in SAP Community?

Since 2019, I have been building the SAP Community in Silesia, in Katowice. I invested a significant amount of my personal time in this, but it was worth it! Currently, our Katowice Community: https://community.sap.com/t5/katowice/gh-p/katowice is a strong group of specialists who enjoy each other's company. It has always been my idea to surround myself with SAP experts and feel even more motivated to act in my region. That is why becoming an SAP Champion was a natural next step. I am grateful for being nominated to the Community of SAP Champions. I would like to get to know all of you and, in time, be able to say: “Yes, I know this person, he/she is a specialist in ... with whom I had the opportunity to talk/work together on organizing an event / etc.”


How do you learn in SAP Community?
What is your daily/weekly routine in SAP Community?

When I am looking for an idea to solve a problem, I always browse https://community.sap.com/ to see if anyone else has done something similar. I often find inspiration there, and sometimes it opens my mind to a different solution than I had planned.

Besides, I believe that the best way to learn from the SAP Community is through conversation. That is why I am initiating meetings in the region to enable people with different experiences in SAP to meet and talk. It always broadens horizons and often allows everyone to learn from others.


What is your suggestion to get the most out of SAP Community?

The SAP Community is made up of wonderful people. It would be great to have the opportunity to meet in person, especially those who are heavily involved in the Community. I think that at least once a year, SAP should organize and sponsor such a meeting for SAP Champions and Mentors. This would give us the opportunity to get to know each other, exchange experiences, expand our cooperation and much more.

My second suggestion is to develop a prestigious program for speakers at events, which would give them greater recognition and benefits. As an organizer of SAP meetups and meetings, I encounter obstacles in finding speakers for the events I have organized and plan to organize in the future. It is not that there are not any specialists! There are many specialists in the region, but few people are willing to volunteer their time to prepare presentations and lectures. This can be easily changed by following the example of other companies that have a strong community around their product, such as Microsoft. Or create your own program in which SAP would reward the commitment of speakers.

Ewelina's question to you:
What do you think about my suggestions above to get the most out of SAP Community?
Feel free to write whether you agree with those and share your opinion.

entry.title: Re: Adoption of PO price from purchase requisition for co...
entry.content: Go to OMET to define function authorization, Create a new profile say ZEK02, enable 'Adopt PO Price' checkbox and Without Material Master (if applicable). Go to su3, assign parameter id EFB and value ZEK02. This tells SAP to adopt the price from the PREQ when creating the PO — even for materials with PIR or historical prices.

entry.title: CSS in SAC - Borders & Shadows a quick guide to css syntax
entry.content:
This blog post provides a quick run through of the various border and shadow effects you can apply with CSS in SAC,
the examples given are based on the panel widget.

SAC CSS Engine
In SAC, the CSS engine expects explicitly defined styles, especially for compound shorthand properties like border, border-top, etc.
SAC requires all 3 properties to be set e.g. for a border:     border: [width] [style] [color];
e.g.

Outer & Inner CSS Classes
When you open the CSS menu and select any Widget from the dropdown menu, SAC will always show
the ‘Widget CSS Class’ options.
This is the outer class for the widget, below this you will then see the widget specific inner class.

Outer class

Widget specific inner class (button in this example)

 

Styles
The CSS help / example for each Widget type doesn’t specify supported styles
e.g. For a panel widget it simply lists the supported classes – background-color, border etc.

 

It takes a bit of trial and error to find which styles work for each class & widget combination.
e.g. for borders:

Undocumented Style Parameters:
border: double
border: groove
border: ridge
border: solid
border: dashed
border: dotted

Colours

When assigning colours via a CSS class we can use
RGB                                   - Red, Green, Blue
RGBA                                 - Red, Green, Blue, Alpha (opacity)
HEX                                    - Hexadecimal
Basic Colour typed       - red , blue , orange etc.

RGB  or HEX is used when we only want to apply a solid colour e.g.
Red
rgb: 255,0,0     /     hex: #FF0000

RGB 
Each parameter (red, green, and blue) defines the intensity of the color between 0 and 255.
For example, rgb(255, 0, 0) is displayed as red, because red is set to its highest value (255) and the others are set to 0.

To display black, set all color parameters to 0, like this: rgb(0, 0, 0).
To display white, set all color parameters to 255, like this: rgb(255, 255, 255).

RGBA
Is used when we want to define colour & opacity, the Alpha (A) value can be between 0 &1
e.g.  rgba(255,0,0,0.2) sets the opacity to 20% 

Borders

Documented Properties:  (listed in the SAC CSS menu)
border, border-top, border-right, border-bottom, border-left, opacity
*        Descendants: N/A;
*        Pseudos: N/A;

Undocumented Style Parameters:
border: double
border: groove
border: ridge
border: solid
border: dashed
border: dotted

Border Examples

Solid border

.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }
/* Solid black border, 6px wide all-round the widget

Applies a solid border to a widget 

Top Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-top: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }         

Bottom Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-bottom: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }

Left Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-left: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }

Right Border
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border-right: 6px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);  }

 

Double lined border
Applies a double border to a widget.                                                     
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 6px double rgba(34, 54, 73, 0.5);  }

Groove border
Applies a groove style border to a widget.
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px groove rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }          

Ridge border
Applies a ridge style border to a widget.                                                     
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px ridge rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }

Dotted border
Applies a dotted style border to a widget.    
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px dotted rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }                                             

Dashed border
Applies a dashed style border to a widget.    
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
      border: 10px dashed rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);  }                                        


Multi coloured borders
Applies colour to top and bottom 20px wide borders.   
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget {
    border-top:    20px solid rgba(255, 201, 51, 0.9);
    border-bottom: 20px solid red;   }         

Apply multiple border styles in a CSS class
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
border-top:4px solid #FFC933;
border-right: 4px dashed #CCC;
border-bottom: 4px dotted rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);
border-left: 4px solid rgb(100, 100, 255);      }


Note how we are able to mix and match border styles, we can also interchangeably use RGB , RGBA & HEX for the colour coding.

 

Shadow
Documented Properties:  (listed in the SAC CSS menu)
box-shadow
*        Descendants: N/A;
*        Pseudos: N/A;
Undocumented Properties:
inset

Box Shadow
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget { box-shadow: 5px 5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }

Explanation
box-shadow adds a shadow effect around the element’s box.
5px 5px → the horizontal and vertical offset of the shadow.
10px → the blur radius (how soft or sharp the shadow is).
rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3) → the color of the shadow: black (0,0,0) with 30% transparency.

Have a play with the parameters, for example set the offset values to -5px   and the shadow will appear on the left and top of the widget.
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget { box-shadow: ---5px -5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }



Inset Box Shadow
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget { box-shadow: inset 5px 5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }

Stacked Inset Shadow
Combines inset shadow with an outer shadow, making the panel appear raised but with an inner depth.                
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget {
    box-shadow: inset 5px 5px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3),
                                            8px 8px 15px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);  }

One-Sided Inset Shadow
Creates a shadow only on the left inner side of the panel.      
.my-css-class.sap-custom-panel-widget {
    box-shadow: inset 10px 0px 10px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3); }

Multiple Shadows
Combines inset shadow with an outer shadow,
making the panel appear raised but with an inner depth.
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget { 
        box-shadow:
               inset 3px 3px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3),
               inset -3px -3px 8px rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.2); }                

Hard Edged Shadow
To create a solid, cut-out like effect, set the blur radius (third value) to 0px.    
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {    box-shadow: inset 5px 5px 0px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5); }

Opacity – Box Shadow Combo
Set the panel opacity to 85% and apply a box shadow     
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {   
          opacity: 0.85;
          box-shadow: inset 0px 0px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);  }            

Glow Effect Shadow
Applies a coloured glow effect border to a panel.                                  
.my-css-class .sap-custom-panel-widget {
        box-shadow:
        0px 0px 15px rgba(0, 255, 255, 0.6);  }   /* Cyan glow */

entry.title: Re: Using Log Buyoff for Process Orders in SAP DM.
entry.content:
Hi,

Why not build a custom buyoff plugin and integrate it directly into your Order POD?

In our case, I created a custom plugin that simply displays a button. This button is dynamically enabled or disabled based on whether the user selects an operation in the Operation plugin—this behavior is tied to the POD context (specifically, by reading data inside the pod selection model and using POD's event to interact with).

When the user clicks the button, I retrieve context data from the POD (such as order, workcenter, user labor-in status, operation, etc.) and display a custom UI5 interface to handle the customer required logic (in my scenario i build a custom Create Alert, custom --> not using standard alert plugin!).

You can implement your own custom buyoff logic and trigger a PPD to log the buyoff accordingly.

It should work!

entry.title: Re: Integrating Legacy SAP Systems with Third Party iPaaS...
entry.content:
Updating older SAP systems to work with modern cloud apps is a smart business decision. While these SAP systems are still very useful, they weren't designed to easily connect with today's cloud-based software. This is where integration platforms come in.

Tools like Celigo offer ready-made connections and workflows that make it easy for your SAP system and new cloud apps to share data. You don't need to spend a lot of time and money on complex, custom-built solutions.

The key is that these platforms create a bridge between your old and new systems. This allows your business to run smoothly without needing to completely replace your existing technology.

Another option to consider is APPSeCONNECT. This platform offers specific solutions for connecting SAP systems with a variety of other applications. It's a great way to link everything together and prepare your business for the future.

In essence, you can modernize your older systems without major disruption. With the right tools, whether it's Celigo or APPSeCONNECT, you can bring your existing technology into the future without starting over.

entry.title: Re: Deviating number of table entries after ugprade to S4
entry.content:
You can find Documentation of Table Changes in SAP Simplification Item List. SAP provides a comprehensive list of changes in each S/4HANA release by which you can filter by version (e.g., S/4HANA 2023), look for items tagged with Table changes, Customizing impact and Data model simplification. This catalog explains which tables are deprecated, which are replaced or merged and what new tables are introduced.

SAP’s official upgrade guide outlines Technical upgrade steps, Data conversion logic and Configuration changes. You can find it on SAP Help Portal;  search for “Upgrade Guide for SAP S/4HANA”.

During migration, SAP recommends running:

 

  • Simplification Item Check (SI Check) — identifies impacted objects
  • PRECHEK_UPGRADATION_REPORT — validates readiness and highlights changes
  • SUM logs — Software Update Manager logs contain detailed table-level changes

These reports can be archived and referenced for audit documentation.

Some community articles like this Blog provide insights into table-level changes. It explains why certain customizing tables may have more or fewer entries post-migration.

entry.title: Re: Sales Document Approval – Standard Workflow : Re-Appr...
entry.content:
Hi @cwagner7364 

Thanks for the clarity on that behaviour.

Yes, I agree. If you leave the approval reason blank in the SD_APM_SET_APPROVAL_REASON BADI, the system won’t keep the “Released” status. It moves the document to “In Approval” by default. This is standard logic as outlined in KBA 3092828. 

To avoid this:

  • You must set an approval reason (even an innocuous one like "000").
  • Your workflow must support that reason explicitly, otherwise the document stalls without an assigned approver.

If you wish to preserve the previous approval status, the BADI logic should:

  • Detect whether a critical field was changed for example the “price” or “quantity”
  • Re-instate the previously used approval reason (e.g. "001") to enable the workflow status to remain “Released.”

What I suggest you do next:

  1. Set an approval reason, even if it's a neutral or generic reason like "000" or "NONE" that your workflow is designed to recognize, but be careful:
  2. Ensure your workflow start condition includes this neutral reason so the document remains fully approved or bypasses workflow.
  3. If you definitely want to retain “Released” status, the BADI logic must explicitly set the same previously approved reason to ensure that the workflow logic remains intact.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Incorrect scale level picked during final settlement...
entry.content:
Hi @drahul ,

It sounds like you're focusing on a specific invoice quantity, but I recommend first verifying whether the Final Settlement is actually considering additional invoices as part of the business volume. You can check this using the report WB2R_BVDETAIL for the relevant Condition Contract and Settlement Document number.

Also, review the quantities retrieved per material in the Final Settlement document. SAP CCM aggregates the entire business volume relevant to the contract and creates settlement document line items based on the defined split criteria. This means, for example, that if Material A appears in multiple invoices relevant to the contract, the system will summarize all occurrences into a single line item.

It's important to note that Condition Contract Settlement in SAP CCM is designed to work on a cumulative basis, not invoice by invoice.

If your Final Settlement is truly only picking up one invoice, it likely indicates an issue with your pricing configuration or access sequence, rather than a limitation of the standard functionality. In standard scenarios with best practice configuration, this process should work as expected.

Best regards,
Gauthier VICTOR

entry.title: Re: Decoupling Strategies for HTTP-Based Integrations in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Hi Jiri,

Great composition of possibilities !

I would say the least desirable option is async SOAP, as it lacks built-in persistence/queuing capabilities. Generally, asynchronous processing should be paired with a persistence layer. Given that the sender receives a positive acknowledgment upfront, it won't be able to retry if any errors occur during processing.

DataStore isn't designed for messaging purposes like JMS, especially in high-volume scenarios. However, since the DataStore sender adapter was released, it now offers automatic retries (with exponential backoff and maximum retry time - similar to the JMS sender adapter) and near-real-time processing (as the poll interval can be set to as low as 1 second). Functionality is there, no need to create scheduled iflows manually anymore. Please check: https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/data-store-sender-adapter

Overall, I can't think of any use case where JMS would be superior to DataStore in your scenario. Perhaps one advantage of DataStore is that we can save a custom ID in the DataStore entry and filter based on it (making tracking easier). For JMS messages, IDs are automatically generated and filtering possible only via Message ID. I hope some day it will also be possible for JMS.

If we only need internal persistence for a point-to-point scenario, I generally wouldn't recommend EventMesh or any other event broker. Although one advantage of an external broker can be that it can help overcome JMS resource limitations (such as the number of queues, total size, etc.) which as you mentioned can quickly become a problem if you use AS2 sender adapters without TPM or per company , not generic inbound iflow.

Last point - maybe the sender system should increase the timeout if it cares about processing status anyway. If not, then it's not really a synchronous interface. And maybe it should not be, considering the fact that it runs over 1 minute 🙂

entry.title: SAP IBP new Integration Option : Introducing SAP Cloud Integration from BTP's Integration Suite
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

 

Recently, changes in the integration layer for SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) were announced as you can read in the following blog entry : Enhancing SAP IBP integration - Evolution and Innovation or see in the latest IBP What’s New webinar for 2508 with regards to Integration.

📣 ⚠️ Key message ⚠️📣

While SAP Cloud Integration for Data Services (CI-DS) will remain the main ETL solution for a 1000+ existing IBP customers, especially when it comes to integrating time series data, innovations in the IBP model structure (The new harmonized planning area allowing to support both time series and order based planning) have led us to rethink and improve the integration layer for a more scalable and efficient offering.

Rest assured: there is currently no plan to sunset CI-DS, it will continue to be supported by SAP in the future.

For new IBP customers post release 2508, we encourage making use of the new harmonized planning area (sample PA called SAPIBP2) whose main integration method is SAP Real Time Integration (RTI) for master data as well as orders & stock. Anything else, especially time series data, can be covered with SAP Cloud Integration (CI)—part of SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Integration Suite.

So what is SAP CI and how can we use it to integrate data between SAP IBP and SAP S/4HANA (private cloud / on premise) ?

This is what we will cover in this blog series.

 

Overview: What is SAP Cloud Integration?

SAP Cloud Integration is the central, cloud‑native iPaaS offering within SAP Integration Suite, enabling seamless connection of cloud and on‑premise applications, both SAP and non‑SAP.

Core capabilities include:

  • Integration flow design & monitoring via web‑based tooling,
  • Support for synchronous and asynchronous patterns, event‑based, batch, messaging, content‑based routing, IDoc/RFC flows,
  • Built‑in security, governance, and stateful processing with error handling and restart capabilities.

 

Key Capabilities & Integration Patterns

  • Prepacked integration content, accelerators and templates supported,
  • Full lifecycle support: orchestration, transformation, routing, monitoring,
  • Protocol & messaging flexibility: HTTP/HTTPS, SOAP, REST/OData, RFC/IDoc, SFTP, JMS, AS2, mail, LDAP, JDBC, plus a custom Adapter SDK,
  • Custom adapter framework: build your own adapters to any protocol or legacy system.

 

Integration Options: Adapters, APIs, Open Connectors

  • SAP‑standard adapters: e.g. SuccessFactors, Ariba, S/4HANA, Concur, SAP CRM, SAP Cloud for Customer (C4C) and now IBP,
  • Open Connectors: simplified connectivity to third‑party SaaS such as Salesforce, AWS, Dynamics CRM,
  • APIs / web services: support for REST/OData or SOAP interfaces,
  • File‑based and database integration: via SFTP, JDBC adapters,
  • Messaging-based integration: JMS, AS2 to handle enterprise messaging.

 

Let’s now focus on the initial configuration needed in the various systems to secure this IBP to S/4HANA (private/on prem) integration via CI. 

 

Initial Setup in BTP

To be able to use CI for integration purposes with IBP, you first need the following:

  • A license to SAP BTP (Purchase at SAP Store),
  • A global account must have been setup for your company, check with your IT team as it is possible you already have one for other purposes if you have a BTP license. In that case, you can use the same.
  • You need to create a BTP subaccount to consume the Integration Suite service via your BTP global account administrator.
    • Make sure Cloud Foundry Environment is enabled for your subaccount
    • Note that Integration Suite service runs only on the SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment.
    • To consume this application, you need to create a subscription to the Integration Suite. In the navigation bar of the SAP BTP cockpit, select Services→Service Marketplace. All resources your subaccount is entitled to consume are shown as tiles. 
    • Click on ... (Create) in the top-right corner of the Integration Suite tile. An intuitive wizard opens to guide you in a step-by-step procedure.
    • Check your subscription from your subaccount via the Services→Instances and Subscriptions section

 

  • Now, to provision the Cloud Integration tenant from the Integration Suite in the next steps, you need to add additional role.
    • User Name which should be the email address,
    • Identity Provider choose for example Default Identity Provider,
    • Email.
    • In the Security→Users section of BTP cockpit, select Create
    • Fill in the following on the new user dialog:
    • Choose Assign Role Collection and select “Integration_Provisioner”,

 

  • You can access your Integration Suite subscription as shown below with the above credentials.

 

 

 Initial Setup in Integration Suite

Now that you can access the Integration Suite application, you need to activate its capabilities to provision the Cloud Integration tenant.

  • From the Integration Suite, choose Home from the left side navigation bar.
  • Click on Add Capabilities (or Manage Capabilities if this step was already executed for other purposes),
  • In the first step of the new dialog, select Build Integration Scenarios and choose Next,

 

  • In the second step, select your environment between Production and Non Production and choose Next,
  • Finally in the third step, choose Activate.

 

Once the activation is finished, you should be able to see the added features from the newly provisioned CI tenant on the navigation bar to the left:

 

 

Initial Setup in IBP 

Now you can lay the groundwork on the IBP application side by setting up your communication arrangement based on the communication scenario "Planning – Integration Suite – Cloud Integration Integration (SAP_COM_0931)".

First, create your Communication User that will be called during the integration. Use the Maintain Communication Users application for this purpose.

  • On the Maintain Communication Users screen, choose New.
  • On the Create Communication User screen, enter the following data:
    • username,
    • description,
    • password (this will be used in the BTP application to conclude the setup).
      • Alternatively, you can create a certificate-based authentication method.

Note: above names are set as examples only.

  • Click on create.

Next, access the Communication System application to define IBP as the partner for inbound communication from CI.

  • On the Communication Systems screen, choose New.
  • In the New Communication System dialog box, enter the following data:
    • System ID,
    • System Name.
  • Click on Create from said dialog box
  • On the Communication System screen, enter the following data:
    • Select the checkbox for Inbound Only,
    • Add the communication user created in the previous step : User Name/Client ID,

 

Note: above names are set as examples only.

  • Click on Save.

 

Finally, access the Communication Arrangement application to expose inbound and outbound services that enable the communication between IBP and CI.

  • On the Communication Arrangement screen, choose New.
  • In the New Communication Arrangement dialog box, enter the following data:
    • Scenario,
    • Arrangement Name.
  • Click on Create from said dialog box
  • On the Communication Arrangement screen, enter the following data:
    • Select the communication system created in the previous step : Communication System.

 

Note: above names are set as examples only.

  • Click on Save.

The configuration for integration on the IBP side is finished.

 

Next blog entries will cover the following:

  • start working in the Integration Suite by defining destinations representing the systems (IBP and S/4HANA) the integration flows (i-flows) will connect to via RFC connections.
  • start configuring i-flows, leveraging standard prebuilt CI packages and the ERP (or S/4HANA) integration addon for SAP IBP as a starting point.

 

Sources 

  • Overview of SAP Integration Suite and SAP Cloud Integration
  • Additional information on Integrating capabilities in Integration Suite

entry.title: How to Hide a Combined Field Group (#AS_FIELDGROUP) by Default in a Fiori Elements List Report
entry.content:
I’m working on a CDS view where we use the #AS_FIELDGROUP annotation to display a combined field called “Planned Start / End”.

 @ui: {
  lineItem: [
  {  hidden: true
  },
      { 
      type: #AS_FIELDGROUP,
        valueQualifier: 'StartEnd',
        label: 'Planned Start / End',
        importance: #LOW
         }
  ],
      fieldGroup: [
      {
      exclude: true,
      qualifier: 'StartEnd',
        position: 10 }]
  }
  @Consumption:{
      filter.hidden: true
       }
       
  MfgOrderPlannedStartEndDate;
    @ui: {
    lineItem: [
    { hidden: true }
    ],
    fieldGroup: [
    {
    qualifier: 'StartEnd',
      position: 20 }] }
  @Consumption:{
    filter.hidden: true
     }
  MfgOrderPlannedEndStartDate;

At the moment, this field is shown by default in the list report, but I’d like it not to appear by default, while still allowing users to add it manually via Adapt UI (table personalization). I tried using exclude: true, but it didn’t work as expected.

Do you know if there’s a way to achieve this behavior? Thanks in advance!

entry.title: New tables of tax for Portugal- IRS to be applied in August and October
entry.content:
Dear Portuguese Human Resources Customers,

A new legal change coming up. 

The new Portuguese IRS tables were published in Dispatch No. 8464-A/2025, dated July 22, 2025.

Similar publications are expected for the Autonomous Regions of Madeira and Azores. This blog will be updated accordingly.

The upload files for the mainland (Continente) tables have been made available through SAP Note 3327495 - ATUALIZADOR TAXA: Tax Table Upload Process Starting from the Second Semester of 2..., and are to be effective as follows:

  • Between August 1 and September 30, 2025
  • Between October 1 and December 31, 2025

Please note that the tables should be installed in chronological order.

Issue detected

On July 28, 2025, version 16 of SAP Note 3327495 was released with the file Tab_IRS_08_2025_Cont.csv containg some incorrect amounts, leading to errors in the August 2025 payroll run. On July 31, 2025, version 17 of the same note was generated with the new file Tab_IRS_08_2025_Cont_v2.csv adjusting the incorrect values.

Our recommendation is to directly load the correct files for each affected period:

  • Between August 1 and September 30, 2025: Tab_IRS_08_2025_Cont_v2.csv
  • Between October 1 and December 31, 2025: Tab_IRS_10_2025_Cont.csv

If you have already uploaded the Tab_IRS_08_2025_Cont.csv file, apply one of the following procedures:

  1. Via SAP Note:
    Apply SAP Note 3638265 - ATUALIZADOR TAXA: Enhancement to update records before last load.
    • This SAP Note allows loading the files for the periods prior to the most recent one.
    • After, use the RPUTAXP0 report to load the correct files: Tab_IRS_08_2025_Cont_v2.csv and Tab_IRS_10_2025_Cont.csv.

  2. Manual Update: 
    Alternatively, you may manually update the relevant records in V_T5P1P valid between August 1 and September 30, 2025. You will need to change the value of the last record (MAXV) of each table (T01, T02, T03, ...) from 9999999.00 to 9999999.99, and update the value of the first record from 9999999.01 to 0000000.00.

Impact of these new tax tables:

The primary impact in August and September will be a reduction in tax payments by taxpayers to compensate for the tables from January to July 2025.

Here is an example:

For an employee who is single with no children and earns a salary of €2,500, falling under table 1, the deductions from January to July should be:

Up to €2,432.00         35.50%     €386.72

Up to €3,233.00         38.72%     €465.03

 

Now, in August and September, with the new table, the deductions should be:

Up to €2,432.00         5.24%      €84.57

Up to €3,233.00         7.67%      €143.67

 

In October:

Up to €2,432.00         34.90%     €382.63

Up to €3,233.00         38.36%     €466.78

Thus, see below an example of tax calculation in each month of the year according to the tables to be applied:

entry.title: ¿Cómo impacta la noticia de adquisición de SmartRecruiters en el ecosistema de SAP SuccessFactors?
entry.content:
SAP acaba de anunciar la adquisición de SmartRecruiters, la plataforma de talent acquisition basada en IA y utilizada por más de 4.000 empresas en 120 países 🚀

¿Por qué es importante y llama tanto la atención este anuncio? aquí te lo explico en simple 👇🏼:

1) Suite end-to-end: Con SmartRecruiters, SAP SuccessFactors cubrirá ahora todo el ciclo de vida del talento en una sola experiencia, desde la atracción y el reclutamiento hasta la incorporación, el desarrollo y la retención ✅

2) IA y automatización del reclutamiento: Matching basado en datos, chatbots para candidatos y analítica de funnel de contratación llegan nativos... Queda menos margen para el viejísimo “lo contraté por intuición” 🤭

3) Experiencia + marca empleadora: SmartRecruiters es conocida por su enfoque “candidate-centric”: procesos móviles, one-click apply y comunicación transparente. Ingredientes clave para competir por talento en un mercado de vacantes tech que sigue en alza 📈

4) Ventaja para los clientes actuales de SuccessFactors : Se integrará con la arquitectura Joule / BusinessAI, así que los jobs, skills y datos de desempeño fluirán sin bloqueos… y sin infinitos conectores de terceros 👌🏽

La guerra por el talento no se gana con más manuales de onboarding, sino con experiencias coherentes desde la primera búsqueda en LinkedIn hasta la primera evaluación de desempeño... Esta jugada de SAP demuestra que el mercado se mueve de “mejores procesos” a experiencias inteligentes de principio a fin 👏🏽

Si ya usas SuccessFactors , ¿qué funcionalidad de SmartRecruiters te gustaría integrar primero?

¡Los leo y felicitaciones SAP por este gran paso!

entry.title: New Workflow Service for SAP Ariba Category Management in 2508: Key Changes and Actions Required
entry.content:
The August 2025 release of SAP Ariba Category Management will introduce an architectural update designed to strengthen workflow capabilities by leveraging the SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) service. While there won’t be a change for business users, it is essential for admins to make specific updates to their current tenants. These updates will ensure that workflow processes related to strategy and plan document approvals continue to work.

In this blog post, we’ll walk you through the key changes related to the new SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) service and highlight the actions required before and after the release date on August 15, 2025.

Pre-Release: Withdraw Documents that Are Pending Approval

With the move to the SBPA service, any approval documents that were submitted before August 15 and are still pending approval won’t be processed by the new workflow service. As a result, approvers won’t be able to take any action (approve or reject) on these documents. Therefore, approvers must accept or reject these documents or the respective document owners must withdraw their documents before August 15, 2025.

Once the new workflow service is released on August 15, the documents can be resubmitted to trigger approvals with the new SBPA service.

Post-Release: Update Role Collections and User Groups for Workflow Apps

Transitioning to the SBPA service involves changes in role assignments to ensure seamless access and functionality. Please note that the fact that the Monitor Workflow Instances and My Inbox apps are visible to business users, doesn’t guarantee that they can access the apps. 

As a business admin for SAP Ariba Category Management, you must update the relevant role collections or user groups (depending on your setup) to make sure that business users can continue to use the workflow apps after August 15. Do the following, depending on whether you're using role collections or user groups:

 Access to Monitor Workflow Instances appAccess to My Inbox app
Setup with role collectionsAssign the new ProcessAutomationAdmin role collection to the relevant business users.Assign the new ProcessAutomationParticipant role collection to the relevant business users.
Setup with user groups

Ensure that the IAS user group CategoryManagementWorkflowAdministrator is mapped to the BTP role collection Category Management Workflow Administrator.

Ensure that the IAS user group CategoryStrategyApprover is mapped correctly to the corresponding BTP role collection Category Strategy Approver.

Changes to Email Notification Setup

Email notifications are integral to workflow updates. Whether or not you must change your settings post-release depends on whether SAP Ariba Category Management was provisioned in an SAP-managed SAP BTP account (simplified provisioning) or a customer-managed SAP BTP account (manual provisioning).

SAP-managed SAP BTP accounts

No action needed as email notifications work without manual setup.

Customer-managed SAP BTP accounts

Admins must manually configure the email destination post-release. For more information, see Setting Up an SAP BTP Destination for Email Notifications.

New, Built-In SMTP Server

With the new SBPA service, SAP introduces a built-in SMTP server, simplifying email notifications. After the August 15 release, all customers without prior SMTP configuration will automatically receive notifications from noreply-categorymanagement@notifications.sap.com.

Note

Make sure to whitelist noreply-categorymanagement@notifications.sap.com in your corporate email system to avoid missing crucial notifications.

You still have the flexibility to configure your own SMTP server, whether cloud-based or on-premise, depending on your organizational preferences. If you have configured an SMTP server and want to continue using it, you need to create a new destination SAP_Business_Notifications_Mail . For more information, see Configure an SMTP Mail Destination.

If you used your own SMTP server before and want to move to the new default option, you need to delete email destination bpmworkflowruntime_mail.

Conclusion

The integration of the new SBPA workflow service brings efficiency and ease to workflow management in SAP Ariba Category Management. It is imperative to update roles and address email notification setup (if needed) to maintain business continuity. By following the steps outlined in this blog post, you ensure a smooth transition and maximum benefit from the new service.

For more information, see the following resources on SAP Help Portal:

  • Integration of SAP Build Process Automation for Workflow Management in SAP Ariba Category Management
  • User Management

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud: Embedded Steampunk: C1 Released Contract
entry.content:
Hi, working on s4 private cloud 2023 with the project pushing on clean core and so strict that we cant simply wrap any underlying cds or object release for tier 1 usage, that is quite a painful path.

In 2023 fps2, still quite a lot cds only released for key user, not cloud programming. And for a very simple requirement update maintenance notification, the released BO does not cover long text update, but quite strange is the API able to support long text update. 

And also there is no released cds to get all the maintenance order operation included deleted operation. This causing issue for us to use EML BO to add new operation as we need to determine the largest use operation number and get next available number for the EML input.


We could raise CI but project timeline will not wait, still have to go live on time. 

Probably would think is wise to just mass release all the object already released to key user, also released for cloud programming.

hopefully this suggestion can be considered as SAP keep selling the clean core concept to the customer.
